Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 06:49PM J9W wrote: Cheryl,  how interesting to me that you asked this question because I just discussed this with my BS. In Sept. 2009 I had a mastectomy and lately I've noticed my rib area hurting right where you described ....thought it was my underwire bra. Plus I have new lump on the top of my foob. I saw my BS this week and mentioned these two things. She told me that when she did the cut on me, she actually cut away tissue down by two ribs!  I had no idea they cut stuff out that low but she said that's her standard operating procedures. So, instead of broken ribs, like I thought, she's inclined to believe it's scar issues. And as to the lump on top, she believes that's scar too. I'm agreeing with her since in the last year I've had MRI, bone scan, etc.
Posts.Title: Could this be scar tissue.?.? bigdogmom2 Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 01:53PM J9W wrote: You'll be happy to know the most biopsies come back benign - however, I know that even knowing that it won't help you relax. The waiting is the worse part. If you can, do yourself a favor, and shut off your computer until you get the test results because you'll worry yourself sick. If you can't do that, stay at this web site only because you'll get to interact with some great folks who have been where you are right now. Hugs.

I SO UNDERSTAND why you feel a little crazy - I'm there with you: DCIS, 2009, grade 3.  I'm having my little lump removed next month in my docs office and should it turn out to be anything of significance, I'll post again about it.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2012 10:27AM J9W wrote: Hi Ellen,  wow what a place to be in. I'd be very reluctant to give  them all my nodes because of my fear of lymphadema. Of course, I fear cancer more but honestly, even if I let them take my nodes, I'd still have the cancer fear and then I'd have to have that plus lymphadema. If taking and testing them gave me a 100% reliable answer it might be worth it but I don't feel there are any of those answers out there. Hopefully someone else who's gone through this particular issue will come along and give you some guidance.

Posts.Title: Pain in breasts? mammafox tanlon75

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2011 06:34AM J9W wrote: K-Lo,  I used to be the xmas over the top person......I hand wrote cards to all my family, over 100 people, and they HAD to be in the mail the day after Thanksgiving. Then, any gifts that needed to be mailed HAD to be in the mail by December 7th.  No one made me do this - ya, I guess someone did - but it was me who put those deadlines out there. So, about 6 years ago I called 'uncle' and gave myself that year off. I sent cards only to my brothers/sisters/gram/parents and one or two friends from far away. I bought no presents for family or friends. I don't have kids though. What I did was adopt a family and provided their Christmas to them. I never met them either, which I liked. It was the best holiday season I had in years.....and, I've continued with that tradition. The holidays are great now. We do have a Christmas Eve open house every year because I do like seeing everyone - we provide all the food, drinks, and our very special egg nog.  I agree too about the advertising - it sort of takes away from the specialness of the season.
Posts.Title: Holidays: blessing or curse? K-Lo apple

I miss the beauty of that place but have been living in Florida now for about 10 years and really enjoy wearing sandals almost all year (but I still have my mukluks in my closet for any winter trips to AK). Oh, and I miss the northern lights and cross country skiing.

Posts.Title: Paternal vs. Maternal Aunt BC Lisazc shells43

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 09:00PM J9W wrote: Hi again,  no mine isn't painful.  I had actually thought it was a swollen gland (so freaked out) but my BS said there aren't any glands where I have the lump. Instead of calling her right when I discovered the lump, I consulted Dr. Google and via a search for 'lymph glands near the shoulder' I could see my lump is located where there are deltopectorial and infraclavicular nodes (why I freaked out)....but my BS told me that this lump was too close to the surface for it to be a node - so most likely it's a fat necrosis. However she did state that sometime she's wrong so for peace of mind we should take it out and she said she could do it as outpatient in her office, a little numbing stuff and cut away. Also, it's very little so it will probably be only one stitch - two at most, and a needle biopsy might not get it.  I had been dxd with DCIS in 2009, grade 3, right mastectomy, so she doesn't mess around. Plus, I have an MRI every six months and the one I had in February ended up with a grade 3 Birads of the left breast.  Better safe than sorry, I guess.
Posts.Title: Fat necrosis... Sommer43 marie5890

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2012 10:02AM J9W wrote: Baywatcher,  are you on tamoxifen??? I found that drug made me very depressed although it took almost a year of me being on it before I figured out what was going on.  I remember talking to some friends telling them that I just didn't understand how come I felt close to tears at all times - I was never like that before and one asked me what meds I was taking....THEN I went back and closely read the side effects. I stopped the tamox over a year ago and am back to myself again. Except for the joint and bone pain that still lingers.  Cariboob (love the name!), I too now get anxious about mammos and also my yearly MRI....which is next Wednesday. I thought I was over the fear but as soon as my BS made the MRI appointment, my sleep has been messed up. I was dxd with DCIS in Aug 2009 and had a mastectomy so now have a unilateral mammo and six months later the MRI.

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 08:13PM J9W wrote: Hi Sommer43,  I was told I have fat necrosis, so far based only upon physical exam.  I have a small lump in the front of my shoulder, close to the arm pit, and my BS said fat necrosis. However, next month I'm having an excisional biopsy.  I'm leaning towards it being a result of trauma....I fell last September while running through the woods and still have a bruise on my knee and my elbow is sore as heck still  - so my fingers are crossed that this is just a result of landing harding on tree roots.
Posts.Title: Fat necrosis... Sommer43 marie5890

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 09:58PM J9W wrote: I keep finding there is more and more to learn about this journey. For instance, although lymphadema was mentioned to me, I had NO idea that it really is a problem. After reading here what some people go through with that, I'd be very reluctant to let anyone take more than one or two glands from me. And FAT necrosis - really??? Couldn't they even come up with a better name - when my doc said that to me I was thinking 'great, now my fat is bubbling to the surface!'
Posts.Title: Fat necrosis... Sommer43 marie5890

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2012 11:53AM J9W wrote: Hi,  I don't have the flair for accessorizing so I may not be helpful there - except I did become a whiz at using scarfs draped all different ways. And loose sweaters.  I so remember feeling and looking like I got beat up!  At the time of my surgery I decided to take some good with the bad and got my eye lids done and my chin/neck done. WOW. When I first saw myself in the mirror I couldn't believe I paid to do that to myself! It's a few years later and I'm so glad I did all that. The scars are gone, the droopy lids are gone, the extra chins are gone so in the long run, it was worth it. Keep a smile on your fact, it will be better before you know it. Hugs.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 11:23AM J9W wrote: Hi Sharkbait.....while it really is annoying to be on the six month split, you probably should do it. If you don't, it will be each year and you'll be nervous for the entire year. I am now on the six month schedule of MRI and mammo. I was dxd with DCIS in August 2009 and had a mastectomy. I get nervous each time I get close to test time - but most of the time I just let it go because I tend to believe that with check ups every six months, if something is found it 'may' be caught early.  Plus, I have decent health insurance that allows me to get the tests every six months - not all insurance will allow it.
Posts.Title: Six Months Rotation... sharkbait DocBabs

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2012 04:09AM J9W wrote: Shayne,  I know the fear you are feeling.  I think you should allow yourself to stop trying to hold it together - cry, scream, jump up and down - just do whatever will make you feel a little better. You've already discovered the hardest part of this journey is the waiting, waiting, waiting.  Once you get concrete answers it gets better.  When I got the call that I had cancer, the first thing I did was go eat donuts!  I hardly ever eat donuts because, like you, I exercise just about every day and watch what I eat all the time but that particular day, I needed donuts.  Hugs.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2012 07:52AM J9W wrote: I too end up with a headache and back pain after the MRI.  I'm pretty sure though that it's because I'm tensed through the whole thing so as not to make a move.  I never have felt the fluid under my arm but I do notice it at the IV sight when it starts.  I have never looked at my MRI images because I don't have a clue what any of the images mean and I know me - I'd decide anything I see is bad news. So, I try to only go with bad news when it's given. In other words, until I"m told it's something bad, I go with it's something NOT bad.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 02:17PM J9W wrote: Annie,  how did they know you had an infraclavicular node positive?  Was it swollen?  I ask because last month I discovered two nodes in that area swollen - and they are still swollen. In 2009 I was dxd with DCIS and had a mastectomy on that side. At the time of surgery the sentinel nodes were clear - so at first I just let the worry go but here it is over a month later and they are still swollen.
Posts.Title: supraclavicular node kate73 bethen

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2011 10:21AM J9W wrote: I don't know if this will help at all, and I apologize for posting on the Stage IV forum, but it's something I learned the hard way. I used to have mouth sores ALL the time (not cancer related) and come to find out, I was allergic to an ingredient in my toothpaste. The stuff that gets me is Sodium Laurel Sulfate. Along with taking the recommendations of the others, you might just want to check that ingredients list in any toothpaste she may be using and if it's there, switch brands.

If things come back without answers, maybe all of us in the area can send you recommendations on our docs so you can get another opinion.  Good luck.  J9

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 06:48AM J9W wrote: I had a laproscopic procedure and it was done on a Friday, I was back at work on Tuesday. I too am a paper pusher.  I figured I could be sore at work as well as at home and I like to save my sick time for when I'm really down and out. However, if you are not have a laproscopic, plan on weeks off.
Posts.Title: Ooph kim40 jennyboog

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 09:52AM J9W wrote: I'm glad to see this topic. I too was wondering how, if the need arose and I had to not work, what would we do. I was shocked to find out that any long term disability pay is reduced by any soc. sec. payment amounts.  Not that it matters to me really since I don't have long term disability. I don't suppose I can get it now either. Well, my attempt at cutting back expenses is by not using credit cards. My husband and I don't see eye to eye on this - I am anti credit card and he's not (because we get mileage - but since we never go anywhere via plane I don't see how that helps). I have found that carrying cash makes me a lot wiser spender. When it's gone, it's gone. So, I think VERY carefully about what I spend. Lesson learned:  tell younger, healthier people to get good insurance policies.
Posts.Title: The sensitive subject Bernicky mrsnjband

Posts.Content: May 28, 2013 04:06PM J9W wrote: Boatingirl, stick to your guns! No one told me anything about LE - ok, maybe it was written down somewhere in all the paperwork I got but it surely wasn't discussed up front. I am lucky. I don't have LE and I thank my my lucky stars every day. I was back to exercising as soon as possible - lifting weights too (granted very light weights) and had NO idea I should not have been doing that. I refuse to let anyone use my right arm (MX side) for any blood draws and now the veins in my left arm are pretty much used up too. The last time I had to have an IV inserted, they couldn't get one anywhere in my left arm, and both my doctor and my husband tried to tell me to use the right arm - according to them, my odds were so low of getting LE that I shouldn't let it be an issue. Idiots. Anyway, you are surely doing the right thing. Especially since your insurance will pay for the LE visit up front - MAKE your doctor's office give you the order. Or find a different doctor.

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 01:05PM J9W wrote: Holy Cow!  I was dx'd with DCIS, grade 3, in Aug 2009, and had a mx in September 2009. Good bye right boob, hello new foob.  I didn't have radiation either. I have been worried about a return but until seeing this thread, thought I was worrying needlessly. This is some scary stuff.  I had to stop the Tamox because it caused incredible bone pain - I couldn't even walk up stairs without wincing at each step. So now August is Mamogram Month and February is MRI month. Maybe I should get PetScan month thrown in too.  Crap, crap, crap.....I think now that my 'needless worrying' isn't so needless after all.  Hugs to EVERYONE who comes to this site.  J9
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 03:57PM J9W wrote: petjunkie,  I think it's good that you did share your story. So, the moral is be vigilant.  I had wondered if one could go  from DCIS to something more and now I know it's possible and that others have had that unpleasant surprise. In a freaky way, knowing this is helpful to me. I can now stop wondering if I was blowing my worries out of proportion, I'm not. But the odds of MY DCIS being one that retaliates with some shocking surprise is as low as me getting hit by a bus while out running (actually, the bus thing is probably way more dangerous for me!). Thanks for some peace of mind. May you win your battle.  J9
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets
